musicalLanguage.description: Yiruma's 2001 piece became one of the most-played piano works of the 21st century. It lives in A major but constantly touches the relative F# minor, creating a gentle oscillation between warmth and wistfulness. The melody is built on arpeggiated patterns that flow like water — hence the name. Simple harmonies, profound effect.
musicalLanguage.structure: 16 bars: an 8-bar A section with the flowing arpeggiated melody, then an 8-bar B section that adds harmonic depth and a wider melodic range. The piece is meant to loop and repeat, each pass gaining subtle intensity.
keyMoments: Measures 1-2: A major arpeggiation — the 'river' pattern. Right hand flows A-C#-E in broken patterns while left hand provides the foundation.
Measures 3-4: F#m — the relative minor. The mood shifts subtly. Same flowing motion, different emotional color.
Measures 7-8: D to E — the IV-V, the classic setup for return. The melody rises to its first section peak.
Measures 13-14: The B section climax. F#m with the melody at its highest and most expressive point.
Measure 16: Return to A — the river completes its cycle.
teachingGoals: Arpeggiated melody patterns: the right hand breaks chords into flowing lines. This is the piece's core technique.
Pedaling: this piece demands good pedal technique. Change the sustain pedal with each chord change to avoid muddiness.
The I-vi relationship: A major and F# minor share all the same notes. The shift between them is subtle but emotional.
Left hand broken chord patterns: steady, even, flowing. The left hand IS the river; the right hand is what flows on it.
Dynamic shaping over long phrases: build and release over 4-8 bar arcs, not note by note.
styleTips: Everything flows. No sharp attacks, no sudden stops. Imagine water — continuous, smooth, inevitable.
Pedal is essential. Hold the sustain pedal through each chord, release and re-press exactly on the chord change.
The tempo should breathe — slightly slower at phrase endings, slightly forward at phrase beginnings. Not mechanical.
Keep the left hand quieter than the right. It's the current underneath; the melody floats on top.
Play this piece from memory if you can. It's about feeling, not reading. Close your eyes and let it flow.

measures.rightHand: E4:e F#4:e E4:e C#4:e E4:q C#4:q
measures.teachingNote: A major — the piece opens with a gentle arpeggiated pattern. Right hand: E-F#-E-C# — a turn around the 5th. Left hand: broken A chord. Soft, flowing, like a stream starting.
Still A major. The melody rises from below: A-B-C#-E, then settles on C#. The arpeggiation is the river's current — every note connected to the next.

measures.rightHand: E4:e F#4:e E4:e C#4:e B3:q A3:q
measures.teachingNote: F#m — the relative minor. Same flowing pattern but the bass shifts to F#. The color darkens — same notes, different gravity. The river flows through shadow.
Still F#m. The melody weaves B-C#-D-C# — a gentle turn around the 5th of F#m. The half note on B lets the sound breathe. Don't rush.

measures.rightHand: C#4:e D4:e E4:e F#4:e E4:q C#4:q
measures.teachingNote: D major — the IV chord. The melody climbs C#-D-E-F# — the widest ascent yet. The D chord opens the harmony — brighter, more spacious.
Still D major. The melody turns D-E-D-C# and descends to B. A phrase that rises and falls like a breath. The sustain pedal should connect everything.
E major — the V chord. The melody lifts: C#-D-E, then F# before settling to E. The dominant creates gentle tension. The river quickens slightly.
E to A — the V resolving to I. The melody descends E-D-C#-B, a graceful stepwise fall. Left hand walks E down to A. The first section completes. The river has made its first loop.

measures.rightHand: A4:e G#4:e A4:e B4:e A4:q E4:q
measures.teachingNote: A major — the B section. The melody is now an octave higher: A4 territory. The ornament A-G#-A-B adds expressiveness. More singing, more open.
Still A major. The melody weaves F#-G#-A-G#-F# — a gentle arc. The higher register gives it more clarity and presence. Let it ring.

measures.rightHand: A4:e B4:e A4:e G#4:e F#4:q E4:q
measures.teachingNote: F#m — relative minor returns. The melody descends from A4 through G# to F# and E. The minor color is more poignant up here — more exposed, more vulnerable.
Still F#m. The melody turns F#-E-D-E-F#, a rocking motion. The half note lets F# ring. This is a moment of reflection before the climax.
D major — the melody reaches C#5, the highest note. This is the emotional peak. The IV chord supports the ascent. Play this with warmth, not force.
Still D major. The melody settles F#-G#-A — landing on the tonic note. After the peak, a gentle descent. The river widens.
E major — the dominant. Melody: G#-A-B-A-G#, an arch. The V chord prepares the final return home. Almost there.
E to A — final resolution. The melody cascades A-G#-F#-E then sustains on A4 — a whole note. Left hand resolves E to A. The river completes its journey. Home.
